newsitem.title: USA: NYC sees Albany making few cuts in aid programs.
newsitem.headline: NYC sees Albany making few cuts in aid programs.

text.p: New York City no longer expects the state to make all of the big cuts in entitlement programs, like Medicaid, that it first expected, and thus has slashed how much the city stands to save, city sources said Wednesday.

The sources, who declined to be named, estimated that Mayor Rudolph Guiliani had lowered his projection to about $128 million from the $415 million of savings that he anticipated in his preliminary plan released in January. "So they are reducing the risk by $287 million," said the source.

The Giuliani Administration does not plan to change the capital program it unveiled in January, which calls for it to spend $43.4 billion over the next 10 years, which would be partly funded with $23.4 billion of general obligation bonds. The rest of the funds would come from the state and federal governments.
A spokeswoman for the Republican mayor, who plans to unveil his new budget for fiscal 1998 on Thursday morning, was not immediately available to comment.
